item.title: Template Markdown
item.description:
Reproducible Research

There has been much written in recent years about the concept of reproducible research. A quick Google search for reproducible reaserch, at the time of this writing, returns 281,000,000 results in 0.32 seconds.

As can be seen by parusing the links below, and others, is that the concepts discussed regarding reproducible research define the process of analysis. How we do the analysis is as important as the analysis itself.

The top five suggested websites are

  • a commercial course about reproducible research

  • the Wikipedia entry, a blog post from

  • a blog post from simply stats

  • a page from the Comrehensive R Arcive Network, or cran

  • a page from r-bloggers

Screenshot of a Google serch for reproducible research.

Or if you are more python oriented:

  • There are some scholarly articles curated by Google

  • iee

  • another

  • another

item.title: Template Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.
